item.title: Devolver Delayed Awards 2024 Recognizes Three Games Being Delayed To 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/devolver-delayed-awards-2024-recognizes-three-games-being-delayed-to-2025/1100-6528093/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

As the game industry prepares for Geoff Keighley's annual smorgasbord of news from The Game Awards, Devolver Digital has decided it's not going to wait until next month. Today, the publisher released Devolver Delayed 2024, a tongue-in-cheek awards show recognizing three games that have been pushed to 2025: Baby Steps, Stick It To The Stickman, and Skate Story.

Each game's delay was announced as a specific "award" given to the game against other fictional nominees. Specifically, the awards were named as follows:

  • Best Inadvertent Tripping Simulator - Baby Steps
  • Best Late Stage Capitalism Roguelite - Stick It To The Stickman
  • Best Glass Demon In A Leading Role - Skate Story

The "awards ceremony" then proceeded to a fourth award, Best Color Version Of A Monochromatic Classic. The winner was the previously unknown Volvy's Adventure DX, with a brief gameplay teaser showing an 8-bit side-scrolling platformer starring Devolver's rat-like mascot.

The presentation never actually confirms the game's existence, and Inscryption creator Daniel Mullins specifically says he "doesn't even think it's a real game" when he appears to receive the award for some unexplained reason, so whether or not Volvy's Adventure DX actually exists remains to be seen.

All three of the confirmed games in the presentation--Baby Steps, Stick It To The Stickman, and Skate Story--will now be launching in 2025 after being previously announced for a 2024 release window. Baby Steps was first unveiled at the Devolver Digital Showcase in June 2023, while both Skate Story and Stick It To The Stickman debuted the previous year.

Black Friday rolls on with more and more deals, and one of the offers available now is a pretty great discount on the third-person shooter Returnal from developer Housemarque and Sony.

Amazon and Best Buy are currently selling the PlayStation 5 game for only $30, which is a nice discount off its usual $70 price point. Prime members can get fast and free shipping.

Returnal originally launched in April 2021 for PS5, scoring generally great reviews across the board. Here at GameSpot, we praised the game of elements from shooters, roguelikes, action games, and horror to combine for a "mysterious, moody masterpiece," as our reviewer said.

After launch, Housemarque released an Ascension update that added online co-op, allowing up to two people to play through the campaign together.

Following the launch of Returnal, Housemarque was acquired by Sony. The Finnish studio is now making a new IP that will presumably be exclusive to PlayStation.

item.title: Nintendo Switch Online Adds Three Genesis Games, Including Some Leaving Steam
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/nintendo-switch-online-adds-three-genesis-games-including-some-leaving-steam/1100-6528102/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Not every title from the 16-bit era of consoles is readily available to legally play, but three more games from the Sega Genesis vault are heading to Nintendo Switch. ToeJam & Earl in Panic on Funkotron, Vectorman, and Mercs will all be available starting today. Nintendo made the announcement on X and dropped a brief trailer for all three games.

Three classic SEGA Genesis games have just been made available for #NintendoSwitchOnline + Expansion Pack members!

☑️ ToeJam & Earl in Panic on Funkotron
☑️ Vectorman
☑️ WOLF OF THE BATTLEFIELD: MERCS
Original packaging shown. Contest has ended. pic.twitter.com/83mMTzfl4m

— Nintendo of America (@NintendoAmerica) November 27, 2024

ToeJam & Earl in Panic on Funkotron is the first sequel in the franchise, and it debuted on Genesis in 1993. While the aliens known as ToeJam and Earl were stranded on Earth in the first game, Panic on Funkotron brings the duo back to their home planet where new problems await them. Several humans stowed away on their journey to Funkotron, and it's up to ToeJam and Earl to make things right in this side-scrolling platformer.

Vectorman was a state-of-the-art game by 1995 standards, and also Genesis' answer to Super Nintendo's Donkey Kong Country. Developer BlueSky Software successfully utilized pre-rendered 3D models that made this 2D action-platformer stand out from other Genesis titles. The initial story for the game is similar to Pixar's WALL-E, because the Earth has been abandoned by humans who left robots behind to clean up their mess. The story diverges when one of the robots becomes a nuclear-powered tyrant known as WarHead, leaving Vectorman as the only robot on Earth who isn't under his control.

Mercs--or Wolf of the Battlefield: Mercs--was an arcade title developed and released by Capcom before Sega brought it to the Genesis in 1990. Up to three players could assume control of the covert mercenaries in Wolf Force. Their mission was to infiltrate Zutula--a fictional African country--and rescue the former President from rebels who seized control of the land.

ToeJam & Earl in Panic on Funkotron and Vectorman are among the long list of games that Sega is delisting from Steam in December. Meanwhile, Sega launched a new line of Genesis game-themed merchandise at Amazon. The company is also planning to reboot five of its classic franchises: Jet Set Radio, Shinobi, Golden Axe, Streets of Rage, and Crazy Taxi.

item.title: This SNK MVS Mini Arcade Bundle Just Hit Its Lowest Price Ever For Black Friday
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/this-snk-mvs-mini-arcade-bundle-just-hit-its-lowest-price-ever-for-black-friday/1100-6528104/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Arcade cabinets are a welcome addition to any game room, but not everyone has the space (or budget) for a full-size cabinet. But if you’re looking for a fun way to get your retro gaming fix, take a look at the Unico SNK MVS Mini Arcade Bundle. Discounted to its lowest price ever for Black Friday, the bundle gets you a pint-sized arcade cabinet, 45 built-in games, and a controller for just $69 (was $86).

Unico SNK MVS Mini Arcade Bundle

$69 (was $86)

This is the first major price cut we’ve seen for the bundle, and it’s not likely to stick around once Black Friday ends. The mini arcade features a 3.5-inch display and a functional control panel, though you’ll want to use the included wired controller to prevent your hands from cramping up. Better yet, an HDMI port lets you connect the arcade to your TV for a more traditional gaming experience. Alternatively, you’ll find the standalone Unico SNK MVS Mini Arcade for $60 (was $80), though getting a controller for an extra $9 is certainly a better deal.

Regardless of which you choose, you’ll get to play 45 classic SNK Neo Geo games. The full list is available on the product page, but highlights include Metal Slug, The King of Fighters ’94, Fatal Fury 2, Sengoku, Samurai Shodown, and Top Player’s Golf.

If you do have space in your home for a full-size arcade cabinet, the SNK Neo Geo MVSX Arcade Cabinet and Base Combo is also discounted for Black Friday. After clipping the coupon on its store page, you’ll save $30. This edition features a 17-inch LCD screen, a control panel large enough for two players, and a 32-inch riser that brings the total cabinet height to 57 inches. You’ll also get a total of 50 games, including many of those found on the smaller Mini Arcade.

Beyond these SNK cabinets, many Arcade1Up cabinets are on sale right now. These include the popular Pac-Man Deluxe Cabinet for $399 (was $500) and the Mortal Kombat 2 Deluxe Cabinet for $399 (was $500). For something different, the Atari 2600+ and Atari 400 Mini just hit their lowest prices ever for Black Friday, so give them a look if you’re more interested in retro consoles.
